title: Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infection
diagnosis_topic: Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infection – Fournier’s Gangrene
setup_script: “A 62-year-old male with diabetes, obesity, and chronic alcohol use presents to the emergency department with 36 hours of perineal pain and swelling. He reports rapidly increasing pain, foul-smelling drainage, and difficulty urinating. On arrival, he is febrile to 39.0°C, HR 140, BP 85/50, and RR 30. Exam shows necrotic skin with crepitus and foul odor involving the scrotum and perineum, with erythema extending onto the lower abdominal wall. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident begins resuscitation and antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: - “After 2L crystalloid and initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics, BP improves slightly to 92/55. Labs: WBC 32,000/µL, creatinine 3.0 mg/dL, lactate 7.2 mmol/L. What is your next step?”
- “Over the next 30 minutes, the patient becomes more unstable with BP 70/40 despite fluids and requires norepinephrine. What is your management now?”
- “You take the patient urgently to the OR. Please describe your operative plan.”
- “On exploration, there is necrosis of the scrotum, perineum, and lower abdominal wall. What specific steps will you take?”
- “Both testes appear viable after debridement. What do you do with them?”
- “The testes remain viable but exposed after scrotectomy. How do you manage them?”
- “The patient’s testes were viable but removed. He survives the operation. What are the implications of this management decision?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs appropriate wound care and diversion procedures
dynamic_flow.reply: - “You leave the wounds open with VAC therapy. There is perineal contamination with stool. How would you address this?”
- “You create a diverting colostomy. The patient is transferred to the ICU. What additional postoperative measures will you implement?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to plan staged re-explorations
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Over the next 24 hours, necrosis progresses along the lower abdominal wall. What would you do now?”
- “You return to the OR every 24–48 hours until all necrosis is controlled. Reconstruction will be needed. What reconstructive options are considered once infection is controlled?”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of Fournier’s gangrene as a surgical emergency
Early operative source control with aggressive debridement
Management of testicular viability and coverage
Consideration of fecal and urinary diversion
Postoperative ICU care and staged re-explorations
Planning for reconstruction after infection control
